'''Shaggy parasol''' is the [[common name]] for three closely related species of [[mushroom]], '''''Chlorophyllum rhacodes''''' (or '''''rachodes'''''), '''''C. olivieri''''' and  '''''C. brunneum''''', found in [[North America]], [[Europe]] and [[Southern Africa]] (the latter species is also found in [[Australia]]).

==Taxonomy==
''Chlorophyllum rhacodes'', ''C. olivieri'' and  ''C. brunneum'' were formerly known as ''Macrolepiota rhacodes'' or ''Lepiota rhacodes'', but the name was changed on the basis of [[molecular phylogenetic]] evidence demonstrating a closer relationship to ''[[Chlorophyllum molybdites]]'' than to ''[[Macrolepiota procera]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Vellinga EC |author2=de Kok RPJ |author3=Bruns TD. |year=2003|title=Phylogeny and taxonomy of ''Macrolepiota'' (Agaricaceae) |journal=Mycologia|volume=95|pmid=21156633|issue=3|pages=442–56 |url=http://www.mycologia.org/cgi/content/full/95/3/442 |accessdate=2007-11-09 |doi=10.2307/3761886 |jstor=3761886}}</ref> The subspecies ''Macrolepiota rhacodes'' var. ''brunneum'' was also elevated to species status as ''Chlorophyllum brunneum''. ''Chlorophyllum olivieri'' is a closely related species that is also eaten as the "Shaggy Parasol."

Many reference works spell the epithet "''rachodes''" rather than "''rhacodes''". The spelling "rachodes" was used by [[Carlo Vittadini|Vittadini]] when he first published the species in 1835, but was erroneous as the Greek word ''rhakos'' 'piece of cloth' should be transcribed as ''rhacos''.  However [[Index Fungorum]] keeps to the original author's spelling "''rachodes''" and so that is the form which should be regarded as correct.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/NamesRecord.asp?RecordID=257410 |title=''Chlorophyllum rachodes'' page |work=Species Fungorum |publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens Kew |accessdate=2017-05-22}}</ref>

== Description ==
The shaggy parasol is a large and conspicuous [[agaric]], with thick brown [[scale (zoology)|scales]] and protuberances on its fleshy white [[pileus (mycology)|cap]]. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] and [[spore print]] are both white in colour. Its [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is slender, but bulbous at the base, is coloured uniformly and bears no patterns. It is fleshy, and a reddish, or [[Maroon (color)|maroon]] discoloration occurs and a pungent odour is evolved when it is cut. The [[egg (biology)|egg]]-shaped caps become wider and flatter as they mature.

The stipe of ''C. rhacodes'' grows to {{convert|10|to|20|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} tall and has a [[diameter]] of 1 to 2 centimetres. The cap grows to {{convert|7.5|to|20|cm|in|abbr=on}} across,

==Edibility==
[[File:Macrolepiota rhacodes JPG3.jpg|thumb|left|'' Chlorophyllum rhacodes ''|250px]]

The shaggy parasol is popularly praised as a choice [[edible mushroom]]. However, it contains [[toxins]] which can cause [[gastric upset]]s when eaten [[raw food|raw]] or undercooked, and some individuals show a strong allergic response even after cooking.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}

Furthermore, young shaggy parasols look identical to the poisonous ''[[Chlorophyllum molybdites]]'' (the mushroom that causes the most poisonings in North America yearly).<ref>[http://www.mushroomexpert.com/chlorophyllum_molybdites.html Chlorophyllum molybdites] (MushroomExpert.com)</ref> Checking the spore print is ''essential'' as ''C. molybdites' '' print is green (older specimens have slightly green gills). As a result, this mushroom is '''not recommended''' for inexperienced hunters.

==Similar species==
The shaggy parasol is similar in appearance to the similarly edible [[parasol mushroom]], ''Macrolepiota procera''. The latter grows considerably larger however, and is more likely to be found in the open than ''C. rhacodes'' which prefers more [[shade (shadow)|shade]] and dislikes open [[pastures]] and [[Field (agriculture)|fields]]. Another distinguishing feature is that ''C. rhacodes'' lacks the brown bands that are on the stem of ''M. procera''.
